article.headline: He sold his company for billions, then used almost all the proceeds to invest in two stocks â and only two stocks
article.body: What would Warren Buffett do? Definitely not this. But that didnât stop Ryan Cohen â who sold Chewy CHWY, +4.96% Â , the company he co-founded, for $3.35 billion back in 2017 â from throwing diversification out the window and plunking almost his entire payout into just two stocks: Apple AAPL, +1.74% and Wells Fargo WFC, , two major components of Buffettâs Berkshire Hathaway BRK.A, +0.06% portfolio. âItâs too hard to find, at least for me, what I consider great ideas,â he told Bloomberg News, without specifying exactly how much he invested. âWhen I find things I have a lot of conviction in, I go all-in.â No real estate. No hedge funds. No private equity. No bonds. The same car and home heâs had for years. The rest? âAll-inâ on Apple and Wells Fargo. Against all conventional wisdom. It hasnât exactly been a smooth ride, at last for the latter position. He told Bloomberg News that his average cost basis in Wells Fargo is about $46, having built up his position in the second quarter of 2017 when it was trading at $54. Now, the stock is trading below $32. On the flip side, Apple is doing just fine. It rallied 120% over the time frame and represents a much larger chunk of Cohenâs portfolio. Combined, his two positions, according to Bloomberg calculations, have been flat for the past two years to lag the S&P 500 SPX, +0.87% Â . Nevertheless, Cohen, who never went to college, is a fan of Buffett, whom he quotes often. He knows, however, that his highly-concentrated approach would raise plenty of eyebrows among the âdiversify!â crowd. But âI donât want to swing for a single,â he said. Cohen recognizes most people shouldnât follow his lead. âYou need to have the temperament to block the noise,â he told Bloomberg. âSometimes it feels like a roller coaster.â Meanwhile, the stock market keeps charging higher, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average DJIA, +0.56% building on last weekâs strong finish with a premarket rally Sunday night.
